Situation1: They make weekly phone calls to update their parents on life events and ask about their well-being.
Situation2: Early in their career, they have not yet saved enough for travel.
Story:
Every Sunday evening, I call my parents. It’s our tradition, a thread that keeps us close even though I live far from home. They always ask about my work, my health, and gently remind me of my responsibilities—not just as their child, but as a Muslim. Lately, my mother’s voice has grown wistful when she mentions Hajj. “You’re working now, alhamdulillah. Maybe next year, you can start planning for your pilgrimage,” she says, hope lacing her words.

I want to reassure her, to promise I’ll go soon. But the truth is, I’m barely making ends meet. Rent, bills, and student loans eat up my paycheck. I know performing Hajj is a pillar of my faith, something every Muslim must do if able. Yet, I also know how much my parents long to see me fulfill this duty, and how much they rely on our calls for comfort. Each week, I feel the weight of their expectations and my own limitations pressing in, torn between wanting to be a good child and a faithful Muslim. As I listen to my mother’s gentle encouragement, I wonder how I can meet both demands when they seem so far apart.
